questions.question: What is logical implication?
questions.explanation: Implication: antecedent implies consequent. Truth: false when p true, q false. Contrapositive: qp (equivalent). Converse: qp (not equivalent). Inverse: pq (not equivalent). Importance: reasoning foundation. Application: all conditional statements.

questions.question: What is a tautology?
questions.explanation: Tautology: true regardless of variable values. Example: pp (law of excluded middle). Proof: truth table all true. Importance: logical laws are tautologies. Used: prove other formulas. Contradiction: opposite (always false).

questions.question: What is a contradiction?
questions.explanation: Contradiction: never true (all false). Example: pp (law of non-contradiction). Proof: truth table all false. Avoided: in logic systems. Detection: formal analysis reveals. Unreliable: systems with contradictions.

questions.question: What are De Morgan's Laws?
questions.explanation: De Morgan: distribution of negation. First: negate AND becomes OR of negations. Second: negate OR becomes AND of negations. Useful: simplify complex negations. Proof: truth table verification. Application: circuit design, Boolean algebra.

questions.question: What is a contingency?
questions.explanation: Contingency: truth depends on values. Not tautology: not always true. Not contradiction: not always false. Example: pq (depends on p, q). Most formulas: contingent. Analysis: determine nature of formula.

questions.question: What are the logical laws?
questions.explanation: Laws: commutative, associative, distributive, absorption, identity. Commutative: pq  qp. Associative: (pq)r  p(qr). Identity: pT  p. Dominance: pT  T. Application: simplify formulas, optimize circuits.

questions.question: What is the law of excluded middle?
questions.explanation: Excluded middle: either p or not p. Guarantee: no middle ground. Tautology: pp always true. Foundation: classical logic. Intuition: controversial in constructive logic. Consequence: complete certainty possible.

questions.question: What is the law of non-contradiction?
questions.explanation: Non-contradiction: not both p and not p. Guarantee: no contradiction. Contradiction: pp always false. Foundation: logical consistency. Assumption: all logical systems make. Violation: inconsistent systems.

questions.question: What simplifies complex formulas?
questions.explanation: Simplification: replace complex with simpler. Laws: identity, dominance, idempotence, absorption. Absorption: p(pq)  p. Goal: normal form achievement. Applications: circuit minimization, algorithm optimization.

questions.question: What is the contrapositive?
questions.explanation: Contrapositive: logically equivalent to original. Original: pq. Contrapositive: qp. Use: sometimes easier to prove. Proof: assume negation of conclusion. Logic: always equivalent. Different: from converse (not equivalent).
